profile.title: USDA Plants Database
profile.note: USDA plant profile pages are JavaScript-rendered. Full data extraction requires browser automation (Selenium/Playwright).

profile_page.note: Full HTML not stored in JSON. Use browser automation for complete data extraction.

fact_sheet_pdf.note: PDF content stored separately. Use PDF parsing library to extract structured data.

extracted_data.factsheet_text:
Plant Fact Sheet
HORSEFLY WEED
Landscape and Wildlife: This plant is not
Baptisia tinctoria (L.) R. Br. particularly suitable for a formal garden but is at
home in a meadow garden or sunny informal area.
Plant Symbol = BATI
Bees are best adapted to pollinate the flowers. The
dusky-winged butterfly (Thanaos brizo) and Io moth
Contributed by: USDA NRCS National Plant (Automeris io) larvae and caterpillars feed on the
Materials Center, Beltsville, Maryland leaves. It is also a larval and/or nectar source for the
Frosted Elfin (Callophrys irus). It is the only known
food of the larval stage of the wild indigo dusky
winged butterfly (Erynnis baptisiae).
Status
Horsefly weed is rare in some parts of its range; is
threatened in Kentucky and endangered in Maine.
Please consult the PLANTS Web site and your State
Department of Natural Resources for this plant’s
current status (e.g. threatened or endangered species,
state noxious status, and wetland indicator values).
Description and Adaptation
G
